importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the federal government shutdown and food stamp funding concerns were being actively reported and addressed.
The start date of the federal government shutdown, which directly led to the funding crisis in the food stamp program and other nutrition assistance programs.
The day the USDA notified states of the imminent depletion of food stamp funds, prompting immediate state-level actions to suspend new applications.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which food stamp benefits are at risk of being cut off in November due to federal funding lapse, creating a critical window of vulnerability for millions of low-income families.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to a federal government shutdown.
The USDA has declared that food stamp benefits will run out in two weeks without additional funding, and states are being asked to halt new applications until further notice.
The food stamp program (SNAP) is one of the nationâ€™s most essential safety nets, providing an average of $188 per person per month, with about one in eight Americans relying on it.
The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP in November, unlike its actions in previous shutdowns, and has instead blamed Democrats for the funding gap.
The USDA has a $6 billion contingency fund, but it is insufficient to cover the estimated $8 billion in November benefits.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the administration for halting benefit payments, calling it a deliberate strategy to harm vulnerable families.
The Trump administration redirected $300 million in tariff revenue to keep WIC running, but this funding cannot be used to cover SNAP benefits.
17 states have stopped accepting new food stamp applications due to financial constraints in issuing partial payments.
This is not the first time SNAP has faced funding gaps during shutdowns; in 2018, a similar situation was resolved using a legal provision to make obligated payments.
Advocacy groups warn that Thanksgiving is approaching and families are at high risk of going hungry due to the lack of access to food assistance.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the journalist reporting on the food stamp funding crisis, providing credibility and context to the news story.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing a trusted news platform for coverage of the federal shutdown's impact on food assistance programs.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key government official who directly stated that SNAP funds will run out and blamed Democrats for the funding shortfall.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, emphasizing the harm to vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SNAP is the formal name for food stamps and is central to the article's focus on food insecurity during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Women, Infants, and Children)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is another nutrition program at risk during the shutdown, with a $300 million tariff revenue infusion keeping it operational, but not enough for SNAP.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA is responsible for managing the SNAP program and issued a notice about the funding shortfall in November.

namedEntities.name: Trump Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The administration is central to the political debate over funding, with claims that it has prioritized political agendas over food security.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democrats are blamed by the Trump administration for failing to negotiate a spending deal, which is central to the political conflict.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Republicans are cited as being unwilling to negotiate, contributing to the shutdown and the resulting food stamp crisis.

namedEntities.name: Enhanced Obamacare Premium Subsidies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its expiration is a point of contention in the political debate, with Democrats arguing that Republican inaction caused the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Tariff Revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A source of redirected funding used to maintain WIC, but insufficient to support SNAP benefits.

namedEntities.name: Gina Plata-Nino
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents the Food Research & Action Center and emphasizes that SNAP is critical for vulnerable families, especially during holidays like Thanksgiving.

namedEntities.name: Ty Jones Cox
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and advocates for urgent action to protect food stamp benefits.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amid a federal government shutdown starting on October 1, 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture warns that 42 million Americans could lose access to food stamp benefits in November due to a lack of federal funding. The USDA has determined that the SNAP program will run out of funds in two weeks, with no immediate contingency to cover the $8 billion in expected November benefits, despite having a $6 billion contingency fund. The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP and instead blamed Democrats for blocking a spending deal, while states like New York have criticized the decision as targeting vulnerable families. A $300 million tariff revenue shift preserved WIC but not SNAP. The crisis is especially alarming as Thanksgiving approaches, with food pantries already strained. Advocacy groups stress that urgent action is needed to prevent hunger among low-income households, echoing past shutdowns where temporary workarounds were used.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
